channel.title: Can't attack certain players?
channel.description: On my server, when you first log in, you either have to choose starter == 1 or starter == 2, (2 different teams). I'm just having trouble making it so if someone whos starter == 1, can't attack another starter == 1, but can attack anyone else. Does anyone know how to do this? I'm using AllStar as a base.

item.title: Can't attack certain players?
item.dc:creator: @Envion Envion
item.description:
@Envion wrote:

[quote=“Aftermath, post:32, topic:290382”]AttackingOn is an integer, I assume it’s an index. You’ll have to get the player at that index in the array where the clients are stored. And relating to wrapping the int in an Integer, no amount of wrapping will give your integer a team ID.

It’ll be something like server.playerHandler.players[AttackingOn].starter to get the other player’s starter information. That probably won’t work, change server.playerHandler.players to the array that keeps your players on your server.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: July 23, 2009, 10:10:03 pm[/size][hr]But anyway, this’ll be what the code you need will look like:

if (starter == PlayerHandler.players[AttackingOn].starter) { // stop attacking however you do it on your server }

This is easier to use and more extensible than checking for every possible starter ID if it equals the opponent’s. This checks instead to see if you have the same ID.[/quote]

I assumed that every player has its own object; when loading player data on initializing that object we load their team ID; starterType holds this ID; getStarterType() is a wrapper method to return that ID

Read full topic

item.title: Can't attack certain players?
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

AttackingOn is an integer, I assume it’s an index. You’ll have to get the player at that index in the array where the clients are stored. And relating to wrapping the int in an Integer, no amount of wrapping will give your integer a team ID.

It’ll be something like server.playerHandler.players[AttackingOn].starter to get the other player’s starter information. That probably won’t work, change server.playerHandler.players to the array that keeps your players on your server.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: July 23, 2009, 10:10:03 pm[/size][hr]But anyway, this’ll be what the code you need will look like:

if (starter == PlayerHandler.players[AttackingOn].starter) { // stop attacking however you do it on your server }

This is easier to use and more extensible than checking for every possible starter ID if it equals the opponent’s. This checks instead to see if you have the same ID.

Read full topic

item.title: Can't attack certain players?
item.dc:creator: @Envion Envion
item.description:
@Envion wrote:

[tt]int AttackingOn[/tt] is a primitive, which basically means it is “just a number”. It has no methods. It is a space in memory of type [tt]int[/tt] with contents [tt]X[/tt].

[tt]Integer AttackingOn = new Integer()[/tt] is an object, which may or may not have the substring method you called.

The solution is to have a method [tt]public int getStarterType() { return starterType; //wrapper method to get starterType integer from player data }[/tt] in the player object/class.

Why a wrapper method? Best OO practices (protect the integer from being changed… allow the integer to remain [tt]private[/tt]… allow easy modifications in the future… etc). You could call [tt]starterType[/tt] directly (if it’s [tt]public[/tt]) by [tt]player.starterType[/tt] if you wanted…

[tt]if(player.getStarterType() == …) { …[/tt]

Read full topic

item.title: Can't attack certain players?
item.description:
@11167 wrote:

Are you serious?

Okay. In the example this message is derived from, balance is a variable, clearly. It’s an int, just an int. Ints are primitive, so has no class that it has to be pulled from, if you get my point. And if you wish to say that that int equals something, it must be part of the int object, which is done by declaring:

Integer AtackingOn = new Integer();

@dillingo shut up.

Read full topic

item.title: Can't attack certain players?
item.dc:creator: @dillingo dillingo
item.description:
@dillingo wrote:

[quote=“Tatemo, post:23, topic:290382”]Rofl.

You have declared balance to be of type int…it is a variable primitive, and does not have class mothods associated to it. If you wish to use the .equals() method with balance, you’ll have to declare it as part of the Integer object.

And gave the example Integer AttackingOn = new Integer();

Means?[/quote]
_TM is probably typing a long detailed reply that no one will understand.
